title: 107_hr1621
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001". The Arabia Mountain area in Georgia contains diverse natural, cultural, and historical resources that are worthy of recognition and conservation. The best way to manage these resources is through partnerships between public and private entities. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve protects various ecosystems and federally-protected plant species. The Panola Mountain State Conservation Park includes a national natural landmark, Panola Mountain, showcasing a pristine granite outcrop. The Miners Creek Preserve at South River has evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain exhibit the history of granite mining. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation, and Lithonia has 2 structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, and Miners Creek. It also aims to assist Georgia and the counties of DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry in developing a management program for protecting and interpreting significant resources within the heritage area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State." SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. This section establishes the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area. SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA is established in the State, consisting of certain parcels of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. The map depicting the boundaries is available for public inspection. The Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance will be the management entity. The management entity for ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA may make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They must develop a management plan considering diverse interests and give priority to certain tasks. The management entity for ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA prioritizes implementing actions from the management plan, assisting in resource preservation, encouraging land use policies, conducting quarterly public meetings, and submitting an annual report when Federal funds are received. The management entity must submit an annual report detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income when Federal funds are received. They are also required to provide all expenditure records for audit and ensure receiving organizations do the same for funds they receive. The management entity must submit annual reports detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income when receiving Federal funds. They must also provide expenditure records for audit and ensure receiving organizations do the same. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real property, but other sources of Federal funds can be used for authorized purposes. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study. The plan should consider state and local plans, involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include an inventory of resources in the area. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study. The plan should include an inventory of resources in the area, provisions for protection, interpretation, and enjoyment of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation. The management plan for the heritage area must include actions by various entities to protect resources, identify funding sources, and describe the management entity for approval by the Secretary within 3 years of enactment. The management entity must submit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of enactment. If the plan is not submitted on time, additional funding will be withheld until a plan is approved. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of receiving it. If disapproved, the plan must be revised. After the management entity submits a plan, the Secretary must approve or disapprove it within 90 days. If disapproved, revisions can be made within a specified deadline for reevaluation. After the management entity submits a plan, the Secretary must approve or disapprove it within 90 days. If disapproved, revisions can be made within a specified deadline for reevaluation. The management entity shall periodically review and submit recommendations for any appropriate revisions to the management plan, which must be approved by the Secretary before implementation. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary may provide assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $10,000,000 authorized for this Act, with $1,000,000 limit per fiscal year. Federal share not to exceed 50 percent. SEC. 9. TERMINATION OF AUTHORITY. Secretary's grant authority ends on September 30, 2016.
